к.  M.  T.  Chrimes : Ancient Sparta
631
Errors in the dating of standard publications such as SGDL 4 vols.  1884—86 and Roscher. . .  1884 ( both on p.  xiv ) and C.  /.  G.  Vol.  I,  Part IV ( 1878 ),  on p.  85,  whatever their origin,  should have been elinnnated,  as should the mention of »the new province Achaea ( 146 B.  C.  ) « on p.  51.  The list of errata corrects only seven misprinted Greek words,  but more than three times this number have escaped detection.  On p.  15 9 àgccrconohhrjç should be àQiaronoXeixevrriÇy for the former only occurs at Sparta in erroneous restorations of IG.  V.  i,  468,  614,  655. 
9 -
In view of the importance of the epigraphical evidence for the sions concerning the Agoge put forward in chapter III it is important to examine more closely the author^s treatment of the material which she has carefully collected and arranged in App.  IV.  The list of Patronomoi,  as already stated,  is in many respects unsatisfactory.  Admittedly it is easier to criticise than to compile such a list,  but it must be plainly stated that several of the dates proposed are impossible,  and that more than one name is an unwarranted »doublet« ; and that these mistakes are due to the understanding or neglect of essential evidence.  For instance,  C.  Julius Philokleidas,  dated to c.  120 / 1,  must be put some twelve years earlier,  since he preceded by at least three years L.  Volussenus Aristokrates,  for whom the suggested date c.  112 / 3 is approximately right.  This order is proved by the fact that one Soander,  son of Tryphon,  was a member of the Gerousia for the third time under Philokleidas and for the fourth time under Aristokrates,  as we know from the lists of Gerontes of their respective years.  Another date which if not impossible is extremely improbable,  is c.  85 / 6 for Aeiijua^^oç о наг NeixoxQarrjç^ seeing that Agion,  son of Artemisios,  whose cursus is recorded in full,  held his first post under this Deximachos and his last,  as member of the Gerousia for the fifth time,  under Eudamos,  for whom the year proposed ( c.  140 / 1 ) is approximately certain.  Any cursus involving a span of fifty - six years is surely suspect,  and moreover there is other prosopographical evidence,  overlooked by the author,  which points to a date for Deximachos close to Philokleidas and Aristokrates,  c.  105—12.  Again,  the date c.  91 / 2 allotted to P.  Memmius Spartiatikos I.  cannot be correctly based on IG.  V.  i,  85,  as this list is definitely to be assigned to the reign of Pius,  and must refer to Spartiatikos II.  for whom the proposed date c.  145 / 6 is quite reasonable.  It is true that there was an earlier Patronomos of this name,  towards the end of the first century,  but we do not know for certain that his Roman names were P.  Memmius.  There is a considerable number of other improvements which might be suggested for this list of Patronomoi if space permitted,  but these examples
